Name: 1625 First Slaves
Caption: 1625: First slaves were brought to New Amsterdam
Description: Date that the Dutch West India Company first brings slaves to what is now New York City
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument.

Name: 1635 African Burial Ground is Active
Caption: 1635: African Burial Ground was first active
Description: Estimated date when free and enslaved African descendents begin burying their dead in an area outside city limits due to laws prohibiting them from burying in what was then the city's primary cemetery
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument.

Name: 1653 Slaves ordered to build Wall Street fortification
Caption: 1653: Governor Peter Stuyvesant ordered slaves to help build Wall Street fortification
Description: Date that Govenor Peter Stuyvesant orders slaves to assist in the construction of Wall Street fortification
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument.

Name: 1664 New Amsterdam becomes New York
Caption: 1664: New Amsterdam became New York
Description: Date that New Amsterdam becomes New York
Citation: History.com Editors. “New Amsterdam Becomes New York.” HISTORY, 2 Sept. 2020.

Name: 1673 Van Borsum family takes control of African Burial Ground plot
Caption: 1673: Van Borsum family took control of plot with restrictions
Description: Date that the burial ground plot is taken under ownership of Van Borsum family, who allow burials but also place restrictions on them—when to bury, how many can attend—in addition to slaves needing written permission to travel to the site from where they were housed
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument.

Name: 1692 Beginning of Commons
Caption: 1692: The Commons recorded to be in use
Description: Date of when the Commons is earliest in use
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 1. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013.

Name: 1735 First Almshouse Built
Caption: 1735: First Almshouse was built and used until 1797; demolished for construction of City Hall
Description: Date of the First Almshouse
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 2. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013.

Name: 1741 Conspiracy
Caption: 1741: Conspiracy of 1741
Description: Date of a grave abuse of power by the local government and judiciary
Citation: Sutherland, Claudia. “New York Slave Conspiracy (1741).” BlackPast.org, 6 Mar. 2007. ~ PBS. “Witchhunt in New York: The 1741 Rebellion.” Africans in America.

Name: 1757 Barracks Built
Caption: 1757: Barracks were built on the Commons for the British Army
Description: Date barracks are built on the Commons for the British Army, who arrived en masse in 1756 and were being quartered in people's houses until the Common Council approved building barracks
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 2. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013.

Name: 1759 New Gaol Built
Caption: 1759: New Gaol was built on the Commons as debtor's prison; also held prisoners of war during French and Indian War
Description: Date New Goal is built on the Commons as well as its purposes
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 2. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013.

Name: 1775 Bridewell Prison Built
Caption: 1775: Bridewell opened to help with overflow of prisoners from New Gaol; also housed American prisoners of war during Revolution
Description: Date Bridewell is built on the Commons as well as its purposes
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 2. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013.

Name: 1783 Evacuation Day
Caption: 1783: Last British troops left Manhattan on November 25
Description: Date of Evacuation Day, when the last British troops left New York, which used to be a major holiday in New York City
Citation: Margino, Megan. “Evacuation Day: New York’s Former November Holiday.” The New York Public Library, 24 Nov. 2014.

Name: 1793 First Health Department
Caption: 1793: First city health department created
Description: Date of the creation of the first health department for the city, created in response to the outbreak of yellow fever in Philadelphia
Citation: Hazelwood, Madeleine. “Germ City: Epidemics throughout New York’s History.” Museum of the City of New York, 23 Oct. 2018.
Institution: Museum of the City of New York

Name: 1794 Van Borsum family ceases ownership of African Burial Ground plot
Caption: 1794: Van Borsum ceased ownership of African Burial Ground plot
Description: Date that the Van Borsum ceased owning the burial ground
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument.

Name: 1795: African Burial Ground plot is subdivided and sold for house lots ~ First Yellow Fever Cases in NYC
Caption: 1795: African Burial Ground plot was subdivided and sold for house lots ~ First cases of yellow fever in city; dozens died
Description: Date that the land encompassing the burial ground is sold for house lots / Date of the first cases of yellow fever in New York City
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument. ~ Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.
Institution: National Park Service ~ Untapped New York

Name: 1796 Second Almshouse Built
Caption: 1796: Second Almshouse was built to replace first one; remained in use until 1816
Description: Date Second Almshouse is built and in use
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 2. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013.

Name: 1798 Yellow Fever Death Toll
Caption: 1798: 800 New Yorkers died from yellow fever
Description: Date of yellow fever epidemic with death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1805 Yellow Fever Death Toll
Caption: 1805: 270 New Yorkers died from yellow fever
Description: Date of yellow fever epidemic with death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1812 City Hall Completed
Caption: 1812: Construction of City Hall was completed, atop the former site of the First Almshouse
Description: Date that City Hall is completed, built where the First Almshouse used to be on the Commons
Citation: NYC Design Commission. “About City Hall: Architectural History.” NYC.Gov.

Name: 1822 Yellow Fever Death Toll
Caption: 1822: 388 New Yorkers died from yellow fever
Description: Date of yellow fever epidemic with death toll
Citation: Crain, Esther. “A Yellow Fever Outbreak Made Greenwich Village.” Ephemeral New York, 6 Apr. 2020.

Name: 1823 Burial Ban
Caption: 1823: New burials below Canal Street were banned
Description: Date of first significant burial ban
Citation: Hedstrom, Casey. “The Manhattan Burial Crisis of 1822 Makes Every Cemetery Today Seem Amazing.” Atlas Obscura, 22 Oct. 2015.

Name: 1832 Cholera Death Toll
Caption: 1832: First cholera outbreak killed more than 3,500 New Yorkers
Description: Date of first cholera outbreak and death toll
Citation: Hazelwood, Madeleine. “Germ City: Epidemics throughout New York’s History.” Museum of the City of New York, 23 Oct. 2018. ~ Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.
Institution: Museum of the City of New York ~ Untapped New York

Name: 1834 Cholera Death Toll
Caption: 1834: 1,000 more New Yorkers died from cholera
Description: Date of second cholera outbreak and death toll
Citation: Hazelwood, Madeleine. “Germ City: Epidemics throughout New York’s History.” Museum of the City of New York, 23 Oct. 2018. ~ Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.
Institution: Museum of the City of New York ~ Untapped New York

Name: 1839 Burial Ban
Caption: 1839: New burials below 14th Street were banned
Description: Date of second significant burial ban
Citation: Hedstrom, Casey. “The Manhattan Burial Crisis of 1822 Makes Every Cemetery Today Seem Amazing.” Atlas Obscura, 22 Oct. 2015.

Name: 1842 Croton Aqueduct Finished
Caption: 1842: Croton Aqueduct was finished
Description: Date marks the first time fresh water is steadily and reliably transported to the city
Citation: Friends of the Old Croton Aqueduct. “The Old Croton Aqueduct: An Engineering Marvel.” Friends of the Old Croton Aqueduct, 15 Jan. 2009.
Institution: Friends of the Old Croton Aqueduct

Name: 1847 Rural Cemeteries Act
Caption: 1847: Rural Cemeteries Act was passed
Description: Date marks the passage of the Rural Cemeteries Act which encouraged developement of cemeteries in rural areas and led to the creation of the cemetery belt in Queens and Brooklyn
Citation: Williams, Keith. “Why the Brooklyn-Queens Border Is Full of Dead People.” The New York Times, 27 Apr. 2017. ~ Cohen, Michelle. “Five Million Dead in Queens: The History of New York City’s ‘Cemetery Belt.’” 6sqft, 28 Apr. 2017.

Name: 1847-1848 Typhoid Death Toll
Caption: 1847-1848: Typhoid outbreak killed nearly 2,400 New Yorkers
Description: Date of first major typhoid outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1849 Cholera Death Toll ~ Pigs Banned
Caption: 1849: Another cholera outbreak killed more than 5,000 New Yorkers ~ Pigs were banned from the city
Description: Date of third cholera outbreak and death toll ~ Date of public health legislation removing pigs from the city
Citation: Hazelwood, Madeleine. “Germ City: Epidemics throughout New York’s History.” Museum of the City of New York, 23 Oct. 2018. ~ Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.
Institution: Museum of the City of New York ~ Untapped New York

Name: 1851 Typhoid Death Toll
Caption: 1851: Typhoid outbreak killed more than 1,000 New Yorkers
Description: Date of major typhoid outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1854 Cholera Death Toll
Caption: 1854: Another cholera outbreak killed 2,000 New Yorkers
Description: Date of fourth cholera outbreak and death toll
Citation: Hazelwood, Madeleine. “Germ City: Epidemics throughout New York’s History.” Museum of the City of New York, 23 Oct. 2018. ~ Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.
Institution: Museum of the City of New York ~ Untapped New York

Name: 1859 Burial Ban
Caption: 1859: New burials below 86th Street were banned
Description: Date of third significant burial ban
Citation: Hedstrom, Casey. “The Manhattan Burial Crisis of 1822 Makes Every Cemetery Today Seem Amazing.” Atlas Obscura, 22 Oct. 2015.

Name: 1861-1872 Construction of Tweed Courthouse
Caption: 1861-1872: Tweed Courthouse was built atop former site of Second Almshouse
Description: Date of construction of Tweed Courthouse atop former site of Second Almshouse on the Commons
Citation: Chrysalis Archaeology and URS Corporation. City Hall Rehabilitation Archaeology Project 2010-2011 Volume 1. Edited by Alyssa Loorya and Christopher Ricciardi, June 2013.

Name: 1864 Typhoid Death Toll
Caption: 1864: Typhoid outbreak killed more than 1,000 New Yorkers
Description: Date of major typhoid outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1865 Typhoid Death Toll
Caption: 1865: Typhoid outbreak killed more than 1,000 New Yorkers
Description: Date of major typhoid outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1866 Cholera Death Toll
Caption: 1866: Another cholera outbreak killed 1,100 New Yorkers
Description: Date of fifth cholera outbreak and death toll
Citation: Hazelwood, Madeleine. “Germ City: Epidemics throughout New York’s History.” Museum of the City of New York, 23 Oct. 2018. ~ Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.
Institution: Museum of the City of New York ~ Untapped New York

Name: 1872 Smallpox Outbreak and Death Toll
Caption: 1872: Smallpox outbreak killed nearly 2,000 New Yorkers
Description: Date of smallpox outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1875 Smallpox Outbreak and Death Toll
Caption: 1875: Smallpox outbreak killed nearly 2,000 New Yorkers
Description: Date of smallpox outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1881 Diphtheria Death Toll
Caption: 1881: Diphtheria killed 4,900 New Yorkers
Description: Date of major Diphtheria outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1887 Diphtheria Death Toll
Caption: 1887: Diphtheria killed 4,500 New Yorkers
Description: Date of major Diphtheria outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1907 Typhoid Mary Identified
Caption: 1907: After being tied to multiple typhoid outbreaks in the wealthy Long Island homes where she cooked, Mary Mallon ("Typhoid Mary") was sent to live in quarantine on North Brother Island until 1910
Description: Date of identification of Typhoid Mary
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “The Strange Story of Typhoid Mary, Quarantined on North Brother Island.” Untapped New York, 13 Mar. 2020, https://untappedcities.com/2020/03/13/the-strange-story-of-typhoid-mary-quarantined-on-north-brother-island/. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021. AND Carroll, Rory. “Typhoid Mary: The Super-Spreader before the Term Even Existed.” The Guardian, 10 Mar. 2020, http://www.theguardian.com/science/2020/mar/10/typhoid-mary-super-spreader-history. Accessed 31 Mar. 2021.
Institution: Untapped New York and The Guardian

Name: 1915 Typhoid Mary Exiled to North Brother Island Permanently
Caption: 1915: Unable to make a living, Mary Mallon resumed cooking and was tied to more typhoid outbreaks; she was forced to live the last 23 years of her life in exile on North Brother Island
Description: Date of Typhoid Mary being permanently exiled to North Brother Island
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “The Strange Story of Typhoid Mary, Quarantined on North Brother Island.” Untapped New York, 13 Mar. 2020. ~ Carroll, Rory. “Typhoid Mary: The Super-Spreader before the Term Even Existed.” The Guardian, 10 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1916 Polio Death Toll
Caption: 1916: Polio infected several thousand New Yorkers; killed more than 2,000
Description: Date of polio outbreak and death toll
Citation: Sheidlower, Noah. “12 Prior Epidemics That Plagued New York.” Untapped New York, 20 Mar. 2020.

Name: 1918 Influenza Death Toll
Caption: 1918: Influenza epidemic killed more than 30,000 New Yorkers
Description: Date of influenza epidemic with death toll in New York City
Citation: Hazelwood, Madeleine. “Germ City: Epidemics throughout New York’s History.” Museum of the City of New York, 23 Oct. 2018.
Institution: Museum of the City of New York

Name: 1981 AIDS Crisis Begins
Caption: 1981: Doctors began seeing first cases new disease (AIDS)
Description: Date that doctors first began noticing what has become known as AIDS
Citation: “HIV/AIDS Timeline.” New York City AIDS Memorial.

Name: 1991 construction begins on federal office building and human remains are uncovered ~ bodies are transported to DC for study
Caption: 1991: Construction began on modern day plot and human remains were uncovered ~ Bodies were transported to DC for analysis at Howard University
Description: Date that construction begins on federal office building located on modern day plot and human remains are uncovered by excavation workers ~ Date that human remains of 419 women, men, and children are transported to DC for analysis at Howard University which will last for 12 years
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument.

Name: 1994 AIDS Death Toll
Caption: 1994: Almost 50,000 New Yorkers have died from AIDS
Description: Date at heigh of AIDS epidemic with death toll
Citation: Murphy, Tim. “7 New Yorkers Remember the Early Days of the AIDS Epidemic.” Intelligencer, 29 May 2014.

Name: 1999 nine intact burials are uncovered during construction
Caption: 1999: Nine intact burials were uncovered during construction near initial discovery
Description: Date that nine intact burials are discovered on the southern edge of the historic ground during construction of the new sidewalk in front of Tweed Building on Chambers Street
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument.

Name: 2003 bodies and remains are returned to resting place during Rites of Ancestral Return
Caption: 2003: Rites of Ancestral Return
Description: Date that some 10,000 participants of the "Rites of Ancestral Return" aid in the transportation and re-entering of the ancestral remains to rest on the perserved portion of the site (each in a hand-carved wooden coffin from Ghana)
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument.

Name: 2007 ABNM becomes first national monument dedicated to Africans of early New York and Americans of African descent
Caption: 2007: African Burial Ground National Monument became first national monument dedicated to Africans of early New York and Americans of African descent
Description: Date when the African Burial Ground National Monument became the first national monument dedicated to Africans of early New York as well as Americans of African descent
Citation: Moore, Christopher. “African Burial Ground in History.” African Burial Ground National Monument, https://www.nps.gov/afbg/learn/historyculture/african-burial-ground-in-history.htm. Accessed 23 Mar. 2021.

Name: The Mystery of the Flying Kicks (2014).
Caption: Shoe-hanging on the powerlines running across street intersection. Seen in the 2014The Mystery of the Flying Kicks (Bate).
Description: Real coordinates of Shoe-Hangings located in Queens NY at the time of this Timeline are located on the Map page of Mapping Cemeteries. The image above is from the 2014 Film, The Mystery of the flying Kicks, directed by Matthew Bate. It is provided to visualize this memorial project without using primary source images that require more research advisement on ethics.
Purpose: Location page, Shoe-Hangings seen in film culture.
Citation: Bate, M. (2014). The Mystery of the Flying Kicks.
Title: Shoe-Hanging in Film Culture(part 2)

Name: 2020 COVID-19 Begins
Caption: 2020: First COVID-19 case was confirmed in city on March 1
Description: Date of first confirmed COVID-19 case in New York City
Citation: Goldstein, Joseph, and Jesse McKinley. “Coronavirus in N.Y.: Manhattan Woman Is First Confirmed Case in State.” The New York Times, 2 Mar. 2020.

Name: Queens, NY
Caption: An image representation from film, Concrete Cowboy (2021) for the Queens, NY coordinates captured by Project Manager, Bri Caszatt, in Spring 2021.
Purpose: Location Page, second data point (chronologically) that visualizes deathscape to the MC audience.
Citation: Staub, D. (2021) Concrete Cowboy. BlackPast, B. (2008, September 22). (1909) Ida B. Wells, “Lynching, Our National Crime”. BlackPast.org. https://www.blackpast.org/african-american-history/1909-ida-b-wells-awful-slaughter/
Title: Shoe-Hanging(s), Queens, NY

Name: 2021 - A Love Song for Latasha (part 1)
Caption: Sneakers tied at the laces on Powerline, with its location "South Central Los Angles, CA" inscribed in the center.
Description: A pair of shoes hanging on the powerlines with its location "South Central Los Angles, CA" inscribed in the center. Seen in the 2020 trailer and film, A Love Song for Latasha (Allison). This documetnary debuted in 2021 on Netflix.
Citation: Allison, Nahli, S. (2019). A Love Song for Latasha.
Title: Audio as a Mode of Mapping
